title: 103_hr3671
content: The Act titled "Tax Equity Act of 1993" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The Tax Equity Act of 1993 includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with subsection (f) of section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amended to add new paragraphs for adjustments in tax tables to prevent tax increases due to inflation. The Tax Equity Act of 1993 includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with subsection (f) of section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amended to add new paragraphs for adjustments in tax tables to prevent tax increases due to inflation. The minimum and maximum dollar amounts for each rate bracket are multiplied by the applicable multiplier based on the individual's primary place of abode, with adjustments made to reflect changes in rate brackets. The Tax Equity Act of 1993 includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The Secretary determines applicable multipliers for each statistical area of the United States annually. If any determined amount is not a multiple of $50, it is rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The Tax Equity Act of 1993 includes cost-of-living differentials for statistical areas in the US. Applicable multipliers are determined annually based on the cost-of-living differentials for each area. If the amount is not a multiple of $50, it is rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The Tax Equity Act of 1993 establishes cost-of-living differentials for statistical areas in the US. The Secretary of Labor determines and publishes a cost-of-living index for each area annually based on average market prices. The Tax Equity Act of 1993 establishes cost-of-living differentials for statistical areas in the US based on market prices. The term 'statistical area' includes metropolitan statistical areas defined by the Secretary of Commerce and areas outside the United States. The Tax Equity Act of 1993 establishes cost-of-living differentials for statistical areas in the US and areas outside the United States. The applicable multiplier for areas outside the US is 1. The effective date for the amendment is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1993, with a transition rule for taxable years beginning in calendar year 1994.
